captions.text:
Reviewing Battlefield V hardly seems fair
when I blew off Call of Duty: WW2.

Going back to tired old WW2 after having innovatively
explored new settings in Modern Warfare and

Black Ops was just pathetic, frankly, and
Battlefield instantly following suit like

a puppy starved of cuddles and bonios is new
levels of pathetic, this is &quot;no-one showed

up to my Babylon 5 themed birthday party&quot;
territory.

So bollocks to it, I played Hitman 2 instead
this week.
Not the first Hitman 2, the other Hitman 2.

Another series with a blind spot for numbers,
which is particularly odd seeing as the main
character is named after one.

Agent 47, Baldy McBarcode, continues the story
that began with Hitman 1, not the original

Hitman 1, the last one, in which he was in
pursuit of an ideological killer, and now

discovers that continuing the pursuit will
uncover hidden truths about his origins.
Oh christ, not again, agent 47.
How many times is this now?

You&#39;ve had more sinister hidden truths in
your origins than the average supermarket
sausage.

It&#39;s probably not worth trying to get your
head around what continuity may or may not

exist in the Hitman series at this point,
personally I stopped keeping track around
the time of the rocket launcher bondage nuns.

But even focusing just on the last two games
it&#39;s probably not worth getting invested in

the plot because the developers certainly
aren&#39;t.

The plot is relegated to cheap as chips between
mission slideshow cutscenes and only seems

to exist to limply sandwich together the usual
unconnected collection of elaborate open-ended

NPC-crowded maps set in glamourous international
destinations, which many would argue is all
you need, but come on.

Maybe the pastry case only exists as a sausage
delivery system but it still wouldn&#39;t be a
sausage roll without it.

Games are always trying to skip to dessert
too quickly.

You&#39;ve got to have the talkie bits at the
start of the Indiana Jones film to put the

exciting action scenes into context, you can&#39;t
just explain the plot in a fucking news ticker
at the bottom of the screen.

And just like its predecessor, Hitman 2 ends
on an unsatisfying cliffhanger.

With the massive financial risk inherent to
triple-A development these days, promising

a sequel once is like dangling your baby off
a high-rise balcony, promising one twice is
like doing the ironing with your free hand.

After all that, Hitman 2 is rather disappointingly
little more than an expansion pack for Hitman

1, so you might as well just watch the review
of that if you want to hear about the gameplay.

It&#39;s still the stealthy stealthy disguisey
disguisey get them alone and neck snappy snappy

definitive Hitman experience, still the poster
boy for cockup cascade where you might as

well reload your last save the instant an
NPC you couldn&#39;t possibly have known about

comes in and catches you crouched over an
unconscious waiter with your trousers around
your ankles.

Again, the game will come across as insultingly
brief if you don&#39;t go along with the intended

experience of replaying each mission over
and over again to beat all the challenges

like an OCD patient in a rubik&#39;s cube warehouse,
personally I don&#39;t see the appeal of doing

that just for the sake of ticking boxes - kill
target with gun, kill target with drowning,

kill target with toilet duck, kill target
with the hind legs of a cat - what I will

say about Hitman 2 specifically is that I
get a strong sense that the series is blatantly
repeating itself.

This feeling came on after I got to the mission
titled &quot;Another Life&quot; set in an American suburb,

which for some reason reminded me of a mission
from Hitman Blood Money set in an American
suburb that was titled &quot;A New Life.&quot;
How embarrassing for you, IO Interactive.

Or it would be, if being a triple-A developer
these days didn&#39;t mandate having your shame
glands surgically removed.

Which explains why they&#39;re charging full price
for an expansion pack and two slightly sucked
gobstoppers.
Let&#39;s talk about another game about assassins.

Although it&#39;s only a game about assassins
in the sense that Back to the Future 3 is
about engine maintenance.

Killer7, a classic PS2/Gamecube era game recently
rereleased on Steam, and the game that put

the &quot;weird&quot; into &quot;weirdo auteur developer
Suda51.&quot;

Killer7, Suda51, it really is a numbers festival
this week, isn&#39;t it; next we&#39;ll watch 2001

and listen to the B-52s and consume a very
large NUMBER of drinks.

Killer7 is sort of a shooter puzzler adventure
game choo choo train simulator where you run

back and forth along a fixed track shooting
multicoloured suicide bombers that resemble

gritty vampiric versions of Morph from the
Tony Hart show.

You&#39;re an assassin who&#39;s actually seven assassins
who&#39;s actually one assassin different to the

first assassin I mentioned and you&#39;re caught
in the middle of a complex global plot involving

conspiracy, multiple political parties and
a bloke with an afro.

To say the developer must have been on acid
would be very lazy writing.

You don&#39;t get much done on acid besides talk
nonsense and stare at the carpet.

You might have fun if you play the game on
acid, but don&#39;t blame me if you end up trying
to assassinate Jodie Foster or something.

Killer7 is one of those games that I love,
but I&#39;m not sure I&#39;d recommend.

Take the sort of usual baseline level of weirdness
all Japanese games have by virtue of being

from a different culture that&#39;s been nuked
more than the recommended healthy number of

times, then add a sort of anarchic post-punk
stream of consciousness where even the art

style changes from chapter to chapter, and
then cut the budget a few times so the developers

have to drop every scene that explained what
the fuck was going on.

But even without understanding what the fuck
was going on there&#39;s still enough humanity

in the main characters that you feel something
for them by the end of their journey, especially

the Mexican wrestler who headbutts bullets
out of the air, what I felt for him was a

strong desire to invite him to my next birthday
party.

It&#39;s a game you play for the surface spectacle
more than the deeper meaning.

Which is just as well, because as a game it&#39;s
kinda shitty.

The challenge curve resembles a piece of spaghetti
thrown carelessly at a wall, between the incredibly

easy puzzles, standard enemies with wildly
varying difficulty and a bunch of obscure

boss fight things where you&#39;re left in a room
with a hostile gunman and a pool cue and a

rubber duck and are just supposed to figure
it out.
The game does benefit from the PC port.

It&#39;s all in lovely HD now crisper than the
Autumn leaves in Paradise, California and

you can play the first person combat with
mouse and keyboard.

Which I guess isn&#39;t a thing on Suda51&#39;s home
planet because all the tutorials still assume

you&#39;re using a controller and you have to
trial and error your way into figuring the
keys out.

And that on top of the game already being
terrible at explaining certain mechanics means

you&#39;ll be more confused than a blind dog in
a small room full of assorted buttholes.

And there are other things I wish they&#39;d taken
the opportunity to fix.
Like audio mixing.

There&#39;s a scene in a burning room right before
a boss fight where the boss is saying something,

and you&#39;d assume anything a boss tells you
in a burning room right before they die has

got to be important, but you can&#39;t make out
what the fuck she&#39;s saying over the ambient
fire noises.

Ah, maybe that&#39;s the point, Yahtz, like that
bit in Evangelion where they deliberately

mute the dialog just as Speccy McCuntflaps
says something important.

Maybe it&#39;s intended as an analogy for modern
times in which important information is drowned
out by sensationalist media.
Urgh.
Don&#39;t start down that rabbit hole.

Maybe me kicking you in the bollocks is a
metaphor for neo-conservative urban renewal
policy.
